review: a game of thrones will transport the reader into a world of wonder, magic, mystery, and warfare. it will seize hold of you the moment you start reading it and never let go. the charachters are not your typical cliche charachters you see in every other fantasy book where the bad guys are demons or dysfigured monsters, they are real people who's every action and choice are done for a reason, for the purpose of outsmarting or outmanuevering the enemy. the characters feel real and Martin's writing ability is absolutely stunning. the charachters in this series are the most fascinating you will ever read. the "song of ice and fire" is so good that when youre done reading it every other book you will ever read will come up short in its quest to capture your interest, your heart, and your mind, they will all just seem feeble compared to the "song".never before has a book brought chills to my spine at the mention of words, or a lump in my throat while reading an intense chapter. just when you think this book cant get any better, it will and with quite a bang.ANYONE WHO DOESNT LIKE THIS SERIES IS ABSOLUTELY OUT OF HIS MIND AND HAS NO SENCE OF TASTE!! when you read this series you will sing and you will dance all of the songs and dances known to man until you arrive at the last most wonderful song of all "the song of ice and fire".

title: Simply put...Amazing
review: This series is a masterpiece of suspense, political intrigue, action, and drama. Easily my favorite series of books that I've ever read. Its gripping from beginning to end.

title: A great Book and Series but dont read if you suffer from depression.
review:
Let me first state that I love this series. These books are wonderful for escaping on a snowy night. The characters, good or bad, continue to forge a place in your heart. The books have everything you would want from a work of fiction, except.

This series is sad. Without any specific spoilers I can say that there is not one thing that has happened in this series that makes you feel good. Even when a character falls in love there is an underlying issue that makes the love a bad idea. The characters you care about are put through one horrific event after another and most of the characters are children. I know the series is far from finished but at this point, every single chapter you can rest assured that the characters you love will have nothing good happen to them. 

Read this series but take a break in between books. There is no rush as the author has very little interest in finishing the series quickly. Otherwise, the chapters begin to feel like a depressing grind.

title: Incredible storyteller
review: I read that HBO was turning Game of Thrones into a miniseries, so I figured I would the book before watching the show. I have read other fantasy series before, but George Martin's A Song of Fire and Ice series blows them all away. Martin has created another world where medieval knights battle and dragons are reborn from legend. Over the series, the Seven Kingdoms are torn apart by war and a battle for the crown. The main story focuses on the Stark family, rulers in the North of the Seven Kingdoms. Eddard Stark, as honest a Lord as they come, is forced to play the Game of Thrones against the sinister Lannister family. Each of the Stark children, including his bastard son Jon Snow, must face the realities of war. While there are touches of magic in the story, most of the focus is on real human beings with no special powers except for prowess with a sword. This series in incredibly detailed, and the story races from one end of the world to the other. The genius in Martin's storytelling is his ability to take the reader inside the minds of all his characters - good and bad. Each chapter of the book is from a different characters point of view. While there are clear heroes and villains, Martin's ability to paint many characters in gray instead of just black and white in vivid detail is what makes the story so captivating to me. Each book in the series is very lenghty, and there are more books to come, but you will find yourself wishing the book was 2,000 instead of 1,000 pages long. On another note, I also find his take on the female characters very refreshing. Most fantasy series focus on only a strong "chosen one" male character, but Martin gives us female heroes as well.

title: My New Favorite Series
review: I dont even know where to start....First off this is one of the best books I have ever read!  If you like Lord of the Rings or anything fantasy similar to that then you will absolutely love the book.  This book contains many different characters and each one offers various outlooks into this new land...The chapters are split up into several of the main characters point of view and really keeps the book interesting which in my opinion makes it even better the LotR.  The story is fantastic and this first book leaves you with so many questions you literally wont be able to wait to read the next one.

title: Masterpiece!
review:
These books are not written for those that enjoy light reading.

George takes us to a very believable world - amazing in scope - and introduces us to characters that are not only loveable, but some that are ruthlessly brutal. These books are raw; do not get attached to the characters! The enjoyment here is in the journey. if you let yourself escape into the world he's created, you will appreciate this series more. Please be patient, as things eventually work themselves out to their conclusion. (not always the conclusions the reader would envision) My only disappointment (and not with this book, but with the series) is that "A Feast for Crows" splits the narrative in half and you are left to wait for the fifth book to see what's happening to the other half of the characters. On top of this, George doesn't seem to be in any hurry to get the next book out, as it was originally slated to be out in December, 2009. A Song of Ice and Fire is/was slated to be a 7 part series, but at the pace at which they are being churned out, George may be too old and feeble to complete the series . . .

The first three books in this series are nothing short of awesome - "Crows" falls short, but it's mostly because of the split narrative. I have a feeling, however, that the fifth book will be well worth the wait!

title: I wasn't sure I was going to like this one.
review:
While I am fan of sci-fi and fantasy, I had never read anything by George R.R. Martin.  I was scolded for this oversight by many of co-workers and friends.  I finally gave in this past month and have been converted to a fan.

Be warned, "A Game of Thrones" is not for the casual fantasy reader.  It is deeply intricate and rich.  While Martin focuses each of the chapters on roughly ten main characters, there are well over fifty full realized characters in just the first book of this series.  It would be very easy to get confused or frustrated in the early pages of the tome, but to do so would be to lose out on the epic second half of the book.  Up until the last one hundred pages, I was still on the fence about this "game of thrones."  Now, having finsihed it, I can't wait to move on to the next book.

As a standalone book, I would not reccomend it; as the beginning of an epic series, I am totally hooked.

title: One Great Book!
review:
I like to give both the positive and negative of any book so that if I recommend it the person knows, even if it's just one persons opinion. I believe this book is one I would recommend to anyone who wants an in depth book that leads to an in depth series. I enjoyed each character or at the very least enjoyed how they related to the overall story. This first book is very dynamic and there is an unraveling of plots that exist in so many parts of the book and if not for the fact this was a fantasy book it could mirror life. I enjoy the details very much and the very real human condition of the characters and what they each have to go through. 
The down side: Like many popular authors, the use of words that are not written in common usage drives me crazy, for example Ser and not Sir to point out just one. I have no idea why authors do this and it hearkens to some old English word that is no longer used. Having said that, this is my only real complaint and the reader does get use to them. A very good book!

title: This is the fantasy fiction I've been looking for!
review: I want to be a fan of fantasy. I try to be. But I often find the writing inaccessible and sometimes sexist. But my husband and I started reading this book and have not been able to leave off reading this series since. The story is epic without being cumbersome. The story envelops. The characters are compelling. It is perfection. Now I just need to find more authors like Martin and I will be a very happy reader.

title: Great Read
review: This is a must have if you like politics, war, intrigue, spies, trickery, and just plain enjoyment!

title: A masterpiece of fantasy
review: Martin can make you care about a character in less than four pages, follow that character through half the book and then suddenly kill the character off. The plot is creative and suspenseful and will keep readers guessing. Possibly the best fantasy that I've read, ever.

title: Hard to Put Down.
review: I have not read Sci Fi / Fantasy in years.  This book was hard to put down.  The author's method of separating chapters by individual was interesting and compelling.  At first I was somewhat overwhelmed at the number of pages, but that feeling quickly dissipated as I became engrossed in the unfolding events.  There are several story lines being absorbed as one entity.

title: Better than Wheel of Time
review: I've considered myself pretty loyal to Robert Jordan and his "Wheel of Time" series, but I have to admit I like this one better! It is similar to other epic fantasy books, but it doesn't have the endless descriptions and drag on-ness of WoT. The chapters bounce from character to character, but each is titled with the character's name so you recall the previous storyline. With WoT, that was nearly impossible for me and I was lost for a lot of the series. The only downfall is that the series is not finished yet and fans have been waiting a few YEARS for book 5....and there's no news of its progress on the author's website (at least, not since 08...)

title: A Fantasy Canon
review:
As reluctant as I was to delve into yet another Sword and Sorcery saga, I am enthralled to have taken the chance on Martin's magnum opus. Immediately the characters take on a visceral shape, from the shaky acceptance surrounding the royal bastard John Snow to the abusive sibling relationship of the last remaining Targaryens, and the reader is swept into A Game of Throne's events alongside its characters. Revealed within the various POVs are an ambiguous blend of strengths and flaws that provide sympathy for even the more loathsome creations. It quickly becomes apparent that no one is safe within Martin's novel, as the most beloved players can be swept away following the turn of a page, and there are moments when the anticipation of a climax demands further reading.

While Martin can be long-winded in his descriptions, the aesthetics and world-building work to evolve Westeros into a rich universe of hope and tragedy. The wealth of research and knowledge that Martin has accrued toward medieval customs and times greatly shadows previous attempts at the tale of the knight and the king. Westeros therein becomes a gritty world composed on shaky ground, one in which the people within are tasked with overcoming challenges and betrayals, and a single decision can affect thousands. George R.R. Martin has cemented his place as a modern storyteller with A Game of Thrones, as the book sets a pace that does not slow down until the fourth book in the series.

title: Great Read
review: This book takes place in medieval times in a fictional world. The plot is full of twists and turns and will keep you guessing all through the entire series. If you are looking a book full of romance, this is not that book. The author does a great job of keeping the plot realistic for a medieval setting. This book has a touch of fantasy in it that brings out the mystery that much more. If you are a fan of Dune or of Ender's Game, then this book is a must read. The only bad thing about the series is that there are currently 4 finished out of a total 7 planned, and the author seems to be taking his time with the rest.

title: I am not alone in this thought
review: This is simply the best fantasy, maybe the 1st of the best series of books I have ever read.  That includes thousands of books of many genres.  The characters are rich, the plot(s) are capturing, and the world Martin created wonderful.  This is a must read, The characters are so varied, from a bastard son, to a dwarf, evil twins , on and on, this is wonderful

title: All absorbing!
review: I accidentally read the fourth book in the series first, based on a magazine recommendation. I had no idea what was going on, but even so, the story telling was riveting. I couldn't wait to see what happened to each character. So after finishing that book, I searched out this first one in the series. Such a rich history, great weaving of plot lines. There was a little too much talk of foods served and armament detail, which kind of drags down the writing-I wished the author could get to the action already! Switching back and forth between characters as protagonist helped me in seeing the story from the "villian's" point of view, a nice twist. I switched allegiances amost as many times as the lords and mercenaries in the book! Unbelievably imaginative and yet insightful when looking into the scheming hearts and actions of so many would-be rulers.

title: Mind-blowing read!
review:
I am a huge LOTR fan, and my only problem with that series was how difficult it would get when you tried remembering the names of people and places.  At points in LOTR, Tolkein would also digress at a leisurely pace and the books would slow down.
However, and at the risk of comparing this series to a masterful series like LOTR, I will say A Game of Thrones is much more fast-paced and has an amazing story!  
I bought it with much skepticism but I am blown away with the author's imagination, the fast-paced story-line and depth of characters.  Every character seems to have a negative and a positive personality, albeit some have one or the other to a greater degree thus making them heroes and villains.  I have now ordered all the other books in the series and am eagerly waiting for the HBO show to air.
Highly recommended read in the fantasy fiction/thriller category.

title: An incredible fantasy novel
review: If you are a fan of fantasy novels, A Game of Thrones is a must read. Beware explicit material.

title: All time favorite series
review: I could not put it down!! Only problem is the series is not finished yet.

title: Incredibly impressed and awed by the realism of the story and characters despite their fantasy setting. Just when you think everything will get its fantasy ending, however, reality strikes back!
review:
Martin's ability to take a world apart and make it seem like your own's past history is an incredible experience to read. His characters embody not just the defining characteristics of good and evil, but an exhausting spectrum of the almost devine to the vilest examples of immorality imaginable.

I knocked a few things in my review only because I am a realist... Let's face it, the new book art is horrid! The previous edition's painted scene was much more of a draw off the shelf, not to mention mucb more attractive sitting on your own!

The book is offbeat, but still follows the basics of map in the front, character houses in the rear. You might need to use these items about as much as you do with Tolkein however, making them much more than just an eyegrab or little bonus feature.

Romance? No not really...

As with most first books, you get a slow start. Give it a couple chapters and you will be torn between throwing it across the room in fury or turning the next page.

Great book for book clubs! Very fun to discuss and almost cultish when you find someone reading it or who has.

I would not gift this book to most. Tolkein level writing is not for everyone and I think only about half the very few people I have recommended the book to have seen it through to the end.

title: A must read...
review: If you're a fan of Stephen Donaldson, Tolkien, David Eddings, Terry Brooks, or Ursula K. Le Guin just to name a few great fantasy writers, and you've never read George R; R. Martin; wow are you in for a treat!  This book is the best first installment of a fantasy series I've ever read!  Be sure if you're thinking about it at all, to treat yourself to this one.

title: Game of Thrones becomes, a must read!
review: Great way to escape from the far-fetched fantasy and bring you closer to real medieval living. The character are well built and the writing style gave me just enough info to want more but not so much as it hurt to leave them.

title: well begun.
review: this is the first book in a series. I found the first copy I saw by accident in a heap of books. I was enthralled. I loved the story, the characters and the world they lived in. I was afraid for them in some chapters and cheered them on in others. I've given this book to many people and they too loved it. We read all the following books we could. I wish we could say we are still waiting for the next book with baited breath but we've given up. The most recent book wasn't very good and its been a long time since it came out. I guess the author bit off more than he could chew. That doesn't take  away from this book which can be read independently and is wonderful.

title: AMAZING
review:
Though at heart I am not a reader of fantasy (trend more towards history) GRRM's Song of Fire and Ice (A Game of Thrones being #1) is perhaps the greatest series in an over-loaded genre.  
The story, characters, and world (based off of England's era of knights and usurpers) are all original yet familiar enough to be completely engrossing.
A Game of Thrones is not only the perfect introduction to a series, the book itself stands alone as a masterpiece.
Not being a true diehard fantasy reader, I think what attracts me so much to GRRM is that the book reads more like an historical novel than a fantasy novel.  Magic and all the usual things found in the genre are either non existent or far downplayed enough to actually feel plausible.

title: More Like a Game of Feelings!
review:
I had heard much about George R R Martin's so called masterpiece, so does it make the cut? well at 800+ pages its a long book does that make it bad?
no but here is what does. First off this book is not recommended for children like at all, I personally feel it should come with a warning as
there is a large amount of suggestive content, so that might cut down on the appeal for some. Now the characters are top notch everyone feels like 
a living breathing person,if your a fan of characters that say one thing then do another this is your book. The writing also is top notch right now
I cant even think of a book where the writing is comparable. 
The only reason I didnt give it a higher rating is because evil seems to dominate good almost the whole way through for every good victory there seems to be three evil ones.
That being said hardcore fantasy fans will definately love this book.
And I think it will become one for the ages.

title: Terrific cast and spellbinding story. A real winner!
review: I hesitated for about 6 months before I bought this book (political intrigue in a fantasy world didn't immediately sound engaging) - but I loved it (and the whole series). Martin has the ability to show characters in shades of grey -- even the evil characters are sympathetic. Highly recommended.

title: Terrific cast and spellbinding story.  A real winner!
review: I hesitated for about 6 months before I bought this book (political intrigue in a fantasy world didn't immediately sound engaging) -- but I loved it (and the whole series).  Martin has the ability to show characters in shades of grey -- even the evil characters are sympathetic.  Highly recommended.

title: Great book
review: I loved this book!

title: Great Novel
review: This book will rival any fantasy novel to date. It has the history of the lord of the rings, however it has a darker grittier feel to it, which is why i would not recomend this book to children. Great work, slow at times, but a great overall book.

title: A slow start but a powerhouse finnish!
review: This is the first book in George R.R Martin's "A song of ice and fire" series. For me I found the book to be a slow starter but a powerhouse finish. The character development and the amount of characters in the story added to its overall intrigue. I would recommend this book to most. I'm an average reader and it wasn't what i would call a fast read but sometimes its good to have an epic tale with some meat on its bones. This book was imaginative and eventually engrossing. I look forward to the second book.

title: Beautiful
review:
I had heard so much of George R. R. Martin's masterpiece that I went in with high expectations. I had heard that it was a tale of sweeping majesty, with characters that tore at your heart. I had heard that few authors could rival the stunning prose. I worried that it would not live up to what I had heard.

I had no need to fear. A Song of Ice and Fire is one of the most beautiful and important of all the epic fantasies. I would not pass this book up.

title: An excellent series; Don't listen to the previous posters comment, he doesn't know what he's talking about!
review:
First off, do not listen to the previous poster.  The 5th and final book of the series?  CLEARLY HE DOESN'T KNOW THIS SERIES AT ALL.  One, it is now a 7 part series.  Secondly, the next book (5) takes place during the 4th book.  He had to split the it apart because he has so many characters and plot lines twisting with each other.

Now, going onto the review, instead of the previous poster bashing.  This was recommended to me by a friend as the best fantasy series he had ever read.  I can say without much hesitation that this is one of the best fantasies every written.  BUT it depends on what type of fantasy you like.  If you're one of those mythical creatures type fantasy readers--this isn't for you.  If you like fantasies with some hero saving a damsel in distress--this series isn't for you.  If you like blood, guts, good old fashion middle-ages killing--then read on.  This is by far, the nittiest, grittiest series out there--that still maintains a story line.

Speaking of the story line--it does take quite a while to get used to it.  Martin's style is very different from most writers, and if you have read the other reviews you'll see that I'm not lying.  When I first started reading book 1, I almost put it down and stopped reading.  After about, 200 pages, you start to get a good feel for this world.  After the first book, you'll start to understand the plot (or perhaps I'm just a little slow.)  That being said, it was completely worth it.  

The characters...  Are so completely messed up it is insane.  Good and evil cease to really exist.  The motivations of the characters move beyond good and evil, into the realm of chaos.  The one thing you can say about Martin, is that you cannot predict how his characters will act, or what he will do with them.  I guarantee you, at one point in this series, if you read it, will put down the book and string off a line of expletives that will leave people around you wondering if you're sane.

Overall, if you're a fantasy reader, you need to have this series on your bookshelf.

title: don't buy this book!!!!!!!
review: This clown refuses to finish the 5th and final book of the series. If you feel like I do, that if a writter is willing to take your money for a series of books, then he is moraly responsible to make a reasonable attempt to finish the series. Don't make the mistake that I and many others made of getting involved in this losers work.

title: An Overall Great Fantasy Adventure
review: Mr. Martin does a great job introducing and personifying his characters and sets up the plot elements with startling proficiency. The only criticism I have for the author's style is that George R.R. Martin jumps around from character to character in each chapter which can become a negative distraction for the reader. As well, he could have easily cut out 33 percent of the book and withheld the same substance and effect. With the book totaling to almost a thousand pages, it sometimes seems repetitive and sedentary. But overall, a book that deserves to be on any fantasy reader's shelf.

title: Master Piece
review: I have to say something about the negative response that one person said about rape, murder, evil and such. Thats just simply what happen during that time era. The world Martin describes is so real and vivid. I love the characters and how he develops them. it's fascinating to watch them grow and experience the horrors of life. This entire series gripped me and it never let go. I have been patiently waiting for "A Dance With Dragons"........if your looking for real-time fantasy without stupid magic and dull characters that are so cliche in fantasy, I mean every fantasy book out thier is almost a copy of some sort, but Martin makes this series so real and different from the normal hero's and villians type. Once you finish reading you will then know that you read something entertaining and different then most fantasy you have read.....George R.R Martin has risen to the top of the fantasy world and is my favorite author...If your wanting something to read while waiting for a dance with dragons i suggest you read the Night Angel trilogy by Brent Weeks.....

title: the most realistic fantasy ever!
review: a realistic world (considering its mid evil); and characters who are not just good or bad, but both. it took me awhile to get into the book because the story lines don't come together until later, but after i finished the last page i had to go get the next book.

title: Atypically for this genre, I really loved this book and the series
review:
When browsing the racks I have never, ever, voluntarily picked up any book that (judging by it's cover, *sigh*) smacks of pelt-wearing, sword fighting, pseudo-Renaissance-festivally antics. 

However, a friend recommended it to me whose judgement has been proven reliable, so I looked at the read-it-now pages on Amazon. I was apparently in the right frame of mind to be receptive or maybe was just bored at work, but, I ordered it. 

After reading the first (A Game of Thrones) I couldn't WAIT to get delivery of the second, and after that one, I was amped to get the third. 

A Game of Thrones and the next two volumes are great stories, and told entirely without the sentimental, overwrought clap trap one can encounter in other titles in the genre. In fact Martin doesn't spare any character from any outcome, no matter how beloved or seemingly intrinsic to the plot. 

If you need some escapist fiction, and are okay with encountering violence -- such as someone getting run through with a sword -- every chapter or two, then this is a great book to pick up.

title: Best Epic Fantasy I have ever read
review: This is a great book, and an amazing series.  I have given my copy to many friends all have loved it.  The way Martin writes this from multiple points of view takes a little getting used to, but turns out to be a great way to tell the story.

title: Exciting story
review: Well written story, and very exciting.  Sometimes a bit too violent (including violence against women) for my taste, but still worth the read.

title: Martin is a master of historifantasy!
review:
Martin has created a masterpiece with this series.

Never have I read any novel of any genre with so many characters, all so brilliantly lifelike, believable and richly detailed. He doesn't introduce them too quickly, giving the reader time to get to know and love them, and as soon as a side is chosen, he takes us into the world of the opposing characters, and we come to love them equally!

The scope of the series is truly epic, and while this is technically fantasy, the reader may forget that it's not historical fiction! The style is so gritty and unforgiving that one has no choice but to believe. The fantastical elements creep in slowly and undeniably - a skeleton in a closet, terrifying and mostly unseen.

With character drama like this, you don't have to be a fantasy buff to love this series. All who like sweeping drama will enjoy this fantastic journey.

title: A Game of Thrones
review:
A Game of Thrones is the first book in a seven book series called A Song of Ice and Fire by George R.R. Martin.  A Game of Thrones is based in a fantasy world called the Seven Kingdoms of Westeros, which is very much like Medieval Europe.  The Seven Kingdoms have been united under one rule for the last 500 years ever sense Aegeon The Conquerer united the land.  After a brutal civil war against the "Mad King" the land has known peace with the New King (Robert).  However, this is all about to change if the King's best friend Ned Stark can't figure out why or who wanted King Robert's friend and "Hand" Jon Arryn dead.  With Jon Arryn dead Robert places his loyal friend Ned Stark as his Hand, which has the authority of the King. But if Ned can't learn how to play The Game of Thrones then his term as Hand may become a short one. 

   In the East decendents of the Mad King still remain and are trying to form their army once again to reclaim the Seven Kingdoms like their ancestor Aegeon the Conqueror 500 years earlier.  

   And far in the North there is a Wall.  Built to protect all of the 7 Kingdoms it has been undermanned with rapers, robbers, and thieves.  The wall is accustomed to losing men, but when one of their scouting party never returns they must find out what is happening and if the wildlings are the cause of it all.  

   A Game of Thrones is told through the eyes of 9 characters.  Enabling the reader to see the point of view of all the sides of the conflict.  This is the first series that I have read that does this and I absolutely love it.  Being able to see all the viewpoints of the conflicts in the story is very interesting.  Martin also does a very good job in suprising the reader.  With just changes in your mindset on a specific character who you thought you knew or simply with what you know to be "fact."  I GUARANTEE that you will NOT be able to predict the ending of A Game of Thrones or any of the others.  Finally, I believe that this is the best series out there today and everyone that is a fan of fantasy, mystery, or just reading a well written story should buy!  

***CAUTION*** If you do not like a book with a lot of characters or one where the story is continous from book to book.  Then this series may not be for you.

title: Intense
review: This book was a great pleasure for me. it has been one of the best books i have ever read. For books like this i wish i was a slow reader to savor the moments

title: Cool
review: Books. Buy 'em all.

title: A Game of Thrones INDEED!!!
review: An excellent read that keeps you entertained throughtout the whole book. I can't really say I was bored with the story at any point. I like how it switches from character to character each chapter and you get to know all the main characters on an individual basis. The plot is intriguing and at the end left me ready for the next book because the story could go so many ways and there are so many different things going on that it makes it more vast and complex which makes it all the more interesting. I enjoyed the first book in this saga and am excited to read the rest!

title: A good start to the series
review: This is one of the best fantasy series I have read to date. If you like epic fantasy with raw grit that can make you feel like it's real then you should get A Game of Thrones. Martin has an uncanny ability to craft characters with an astounding level of realism. I guarantee you will find yourself sympathizing with at least one character of this enthralling work. The plot teases you with what is to come in the later books as well. Martin's ability to pen equally enveloping scenery rounds out this beginning entry to the series. A Song of Ice and Fire will grab you and pull you into it's world and you won't want to leave. The only unfortunate part is that you will likely be caught up to the current installment in the series before the next title is released. Don't expect a Forgotten Realms series pace of each book in a series being released within a year of the last. I have been waiting years for A Dance of Dragons and, unfortunately, the only updates you will get from Martin's web-site lately are those of the current weeks' NFL games. Never-the-less, this series is certainly worth the read.

title: Too Old to Finish Series!
review: I did not expect such a long time between books especially the book, Dance with the Dragons.  I will probably not be alive to finish reading this series.

title: This book is awesome!
review: I'm a big fan of epic fantasy novels and this one is awesome. I enjoy the author's writing style. Each chapter is written from the perspective of one of the many (about a dozen) main characters. The story is action packed, with a lot of surprises along the way. As with most series of this genre, there are many plots and subplots that pull you in and keep you reading page after page.

title: Rich, Intelligent, Real
review: "Game of Thrones" is the first of George R. R. Martin's "Song of Ice and Fire" series, and my review here applies to books 1 through 5, all the ones available at the time of this writing. Martin's books have intelligent characters with real personalities, weaknesses, regrets, nobility and failings. The simpleminded, two-dimensional heroes and villains of too many stories in this genre don't exist. The environments he creates are not the mystical worlds of magic and wizards, but rather real places with where dragons, wizards, and mystical woodland folk exist mainly in legends of the past, and set the stage for things to come. Magic is subtle and scarce, and so much more interesting because of it. The language is complex and captivating without being overly descriptive and tedious (for the most part), but be aware that it is for adults and contains adult themes. With more than 1000 pages per book with small type, you certainly get your money's worth. It took about a month to read one of these where at the same reading pace took me about a week to get through a Harry Potter book.
